title: How to Make Blueberry Syrup

steps.headline: Measure the blueberries, warm water, and sugar into a saucepan.
steps.description: Pour 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of lemon juice, 1 cup (200 grams) of white sugar, 1 cup (150 grams) of blueberries, and 1 cup (240 mL) of warm water into a saucepan. If you don’t have white sugar, use raw sugar or caster sugar instead.

steps.headline: Mix the ingredients over a low heat for 5 minutes.
steps.description: Use a wooden spoon to stir the mixture until the sugar granules are completely dissolved. Stir the mixture continuously to stop the syrup from sticking to the bottom of the saucepan. If the mixture starts boiling, turn down the heat. If the sugar hasn’t dissolved after 5 minutes, keep the saucepan on the heat for another minute.

steps.headline: Boil the syrup for 15 minutes.
steps.description: Turn up the heat to medium so that the syrup gently boils. You will notice the syrup begin to thicken. Stir the mixture regularly and scrape the sides and bottom of the pan so the syrup doesn't stick and burn. If the mixture reaches your desired consistency before 15 minutes has passed, remove it from the heat. Set a timer to remind you when 15 minutes is up.

steps.headline: Whisk 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of lemon juice into the mixture.
steps.description: Measure the lemon juice into the mixture. Use a hand whisk to stir the ingredients until they are thoroughly combined. Taste the mixture with a spoon and add a few more drops of lemon juice if the syrup tastes too sweet. If possible, use freshly squeezed lemon juice, as this has the best flavour.

steps.headline: Serve the blueberry syrup with your favourite dessert.
steps.description: This syrup tastes best when served fresh. Pour the syrup over your pancakes, pikelets, yoghurt, cheesecake, or waffles. If you prefer the syrup cool, leave it at room temperature for 20 minutes.

steps.headline: Mix the sugar and water over a medium heat for 5 minutes.
steps.description: Measure 1 cup (240 mL) of water and 1/2 cup (112.5 grams) of caster sugar into a saucepan. Place the saucepan onto the stovetop at a medium heat. Stir the ingredients with a wooden spoon until the sugar is dispersed through the water. If the sugar hasn’t dissolved after 5 minutes, leave the saucepan over the heat for another minute, or until the sugar dissolves.

steps.headline: Add 1 cup (150 grams) of blueberries and bring the mixture to a boil.
steps.description: Measure the blueberries into the mixture and then mix the ingredients until they are thoroughly combined. Turn up the heat to high and wait for the syrup to boil. Stir the mixture regularly to avoid the syrup from burning.

steps.headline: Reduce the heat to medium and leave the syrup to simmer for 4 minutes.
steps.description: This helps the blueberries to break down into the syrup. Stir the mixture regularly to avoid it from sticking to the bottom of the pan. If there are still chunks of blueberry in the syrup after 4 minutes, leave it to simmer for another 2 minutes.

steps.headline: Strain the syrup through a fine sieve.
steps.description: Place a fine sieve over a heat-proof jug. Carefully pour the syrup into the sieve and wait for it to drip into the jug. If the blueberry skins are blocking the holes in the sieve, use a spoon to scoop them out. Glass, metal and ceramic jugs are good heat-proof options.

steps.headline: Leave the mixture to cool in the fridge for 30 minutes.
steps.description: If you are wanting to drink the syrup hot, skip this step. Leave the syrup in the fridge for 30 minutes, or until it is cool.

steps.headline: Add the syrup to water at a 1:5 ratio.
steps.description: Pour 1 part syrup and 5 parts water into a jug. For example, measure 1 cup (240 mL) of syrup into the jug and add 5 cups (1,200 mL) of water. Use a spoon to mix the liquids until they are thoroughly combined. Enjoy the drink with ice, if desired. If you drink isn’t strong enough, simply add more syrup until you are happy with the taste. Mix the syrup with soda water or lemonade, if you want a bubbly option.
